intro: Selinum pseudocarvifolia, commonly known as narrowleaf wormwood, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbrella-like clusters, typical of the carrot family. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands. Due to its aromatic compounds, it has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb.
